results.title: Cartoon connections
results.brief_description: The Simpsons and Dragon’s Lair arcade cabinets symbolise how cartoons, animation techniques and videogames have enjoyed a symbiotic relationship throughout their development.

constellations_primary.name: Cartoon classics and criticism
constellations_primary.description: A whole cavalcade of cartoons have successfully made the leap into arcades and onto consoles, but the relationship between cinema and videogames is far more likely to fizzle out.

results.description:
The Simpsons had only been on-air for one season when Konami released this side-scrolling brawler in 1991. It wasn’t that Konami knew how popular The Simpsons would become, they just already had the blueprints for the game. Two years earlier they’d developed the Teenage Mutant Nina Turtles arcade game and applied almost identical mechanics, play style and combat to The Simpsons. What set The Simpsons apart was the accurate voice renditions of Springfield’s favourite cartoon family, with the show’s main cast voicing the game’s characters.

Dragon’s Lair looks more like a cartoon than a videogame. That’s because it was animated by Don Bluth, the legend behind The Land Before Time (1988), and its LaserDisc technology allowed for dramatically better graphics and sound than other games of the era. It was advertised as the first truly 3D videogame, but maybe should’ve been advertised as the hardest. The timed button/stick gameplay was deliberately designed to eat up as many coins as possible, even though it was already twice as expensive as typical games.
description_for_label:
The Simpsons had only been on-air for one season when Konami released this side-scrolling brawler in 1991. It wasn’t that Konami knew how popular The Simpsons would become, they just already had the blueprints for the game. Two years earlier they’d developed the Teenage Mutant Nina Turtles arcade game and applied almost identical mechanics, play style and combat to The Simpsons. What set The Simpsons apart was the accurate voice renditions of Springfield’s favourite cartoon family, with the show’s main cast voicing the game’s characters.

Dragon’s Lair looks more like a cartoon than a videogame. That’s because it was animated by Don Bluth, the legend behind The Land Before Time (1988), and its LaserDisc technology allowed for dramatically better graphics and sound than other games of the era. It was advertised as the first truly 3D videogame, but maybe should’ve been advertised as the hardest. The timed button/stick gameplay was deliberately designed to eat up as many coins as possible, even though it was already twice as expensive as typical games.

results.title: Bwana Devil
results.brief_description: Filmmakers felt threatened by the arrival of TV in 1948 and sought ways to keep audiences coming to cinemas. One way was 3D movies, and Bwana Devil was the first 3D colour feature film.

constellations_primary.name: Supplementing cinema
constellations_primary.description: A celebration of b-grade cinema's never-ending quest for more, more, more.

results.description:
“A lion in your lap! A lover in your arms! Newer than television!”

That’s what Arch Oboler’s Bwana Devil promised in 1952. TV had arrived in America four years earlier and filmmakers had started experimenting with ways to keep audiences in cinemas. One experiment was 3D movies, and Bwana Devil was the first 3D colour feature film. At the time, industry bible Variety hailed 3D as “the next big thing”, and LIFE magazine captured the premiere with a major spread and this iconic picture of the audience. The film was panned by critics but made $2.5 million US dollars, something TV definitely couldn’t do yet.
description_for_label:
“A lion in your lap! A lover in your arms! Newer than television!”

That’s what Arch Oboler’s Bwana Devil promised in 1952. TV had arrived in America four years earlier and filmmakers had started experimenting with ways to keep audiences in cinemas. One experiment was 3D movies, and Bwana Devil was the first 3D colour feature film. At the time, industry bible Variety hailed 3D as “the next big thing”, and LIFE magazine captured the premiere with a major spread and this iconic picture of the audience. The film was panned by critics but made $2.5 million US dollars, something TV definitely couldn’t do yet.
